article.description: Allan Houston made a tiebreaking 3-pointer with two seconds left to give the Knicks a 92-89 victory over the Atlanta Hawks that snapped a three-game losing streak.
article.headline: Houston's 3-pointer the difference for Knicks
article.linkText: Houston rectifies problem, hits game-winner as Knicks beat Hawks
article.story:
NEW YORK (AP) -- Allan Houston couldn't wait for the opportunity to make up for the last-second shot he missed Tuesday night.
Houston

Playing on an ankle he injured on that failed attempt, Houston hit a 3-pointer with 2.1 seconds left Thursday night to help the New York Knicks beat the Atlanta Hawks 92-89 to end a three-game losing streak. "We have lost some close games, but you also had to make yourself some breaks," said Houston, who scored 32 points and shot 6-for-9 from 3-point range. "That is what dreams are made of, to hit a shot like that in Madison Square Garden." Hanno Mottola missed a 3-pointer at the buzzer for Atlanta, which had its two-game winning streak halted. Houston added a team-high nine rebounds one day after challenging teammates to play harder. Latrell Sprewell had 14 points and Mark Jackson 11 for the Knicks, who enter the All-Star break at 19-28, just ahead of the Miami Heat, who are in last place in the Atlantic Division. "We have just had so many tough, close losses in the first half," Sprewell said. "I can't just see us going through another half that way. I think we are going to finish games stronger." Shareef Abdur-Rahim had 29 points, 21 in the second half, for the Hawks. Jason Terry added 25 for Atlanta, which repeatedly rallied to challenge the Knicks for the lead. "We couldn't quite get back over the hump," Hawks coach Lon Kruger said. "But our guys fought them hard after digging ourselves a hole in the first quarter. "It was a long uphill grind tonight, but our guys battled and gave ourselves a chance to win." Abdur-Rahim scored six points during a late 12-5 run as the Hawks tied it at 89 with 1:50 left. Houston lost his dribble on the Knicks' next possession, and Ira Newble picked up the loose ball, but Terry missed a jumper in the lane and Jacque Vaughn missed an 18-footer just as the 24-second clock expired. Kurt Thomas' free throw gave the Kicks a 63-53 lead with 7 minutes to go in the third, but the Hawks went on a 13-3 run to tie it with 2:39 left in the period. Newble, who signed his second 10-day contract with Atlanta on Feb. 1, finished the run with a three-point play off a Houston turnover. "The most important thing about going up and down, in terms of scoring and letting teams back in, is that you are able to come out with a win and stabilize yourself," Knicks coach Don Chaney said. "I thought we did that tonight." Houston, who said his ankle was sore before the game, showed no ill effects, scoring 12 points in the first quarter. His 3-pointer with 4:38 to go started a 15-2 run to end the quarter up 31-17. Houston made 3 of 4 from beyond the arc in the period. "He has been definitely shooting the ball well even though we have lost a couple of games," Sprewell said of Houston. "When he is putting the ball in the hole, it makes it a lot easier for the other guys." Terry scored eight straight points early in the second and had 15 points by halftime. The Hawks pulled within 46-44 on a dunk by Nazr Mohammed, but Jackson hit a 3-pointer to close the scoring in the first half with 28.6 seconds remaining.

Game notes
Houston shot 12-for-21, the rest of the Knicks made 21 of 53 (39.6 percent) for the game. ... Knicks C Marcus Camby visited his teammates for the first time since injuring his hip Saturday. Camby attended the morning shootaround, moving gingerly on crutches, but did not attend the game. ... New York G Howard Eisley did not dress. He has an upper respiratory infection. ...Terry had four rebounds and now has 501 for his career.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
